movie_review_blurb: If this is the world's next generation of womanhood, that's a century of female emancipation down the drain. Bella's more likely to polish her chastity belt than burn her bra.
Inoffensive but extremely and earnestly dull.
As an earnest and mostly successful stab at what seemed like a flawed idea, Gnomeo & Juliet somehow manages to evoke fond memories.
An engaging and undeniably interesting slant on the source of vendetta and the psychology behind violence and cruelty.
It's not really dreadful but it's not really enough.
Heavily disappointing, eye-wateringly bad dialogue and generally fails to stay on its feet.
Too dull, too long, too Bollywood.
If it had been irony clad it might have been better.
A solid effort from Adam Deacon but not really enough to light up the concrete.
Johnson has just hit rock bottom.
It would be foolish not to experience this film.
It's all been seen before and will be seen again, and again.

It's clear that veteran director Bertrand Tavernier has set out to show the potency and relevance of a classic love story and that period romance is by no means a dead genre. On this evidence, he has a point.
movie_title: La princesse de Montpensier (The Princess of Montpensier) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Honest, beguiling and unpretentious, but not one for the faint-hearted.
movie_title: Living in Emergency: Stories of Doctors Without Borders (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Christensen is a winning mix of sultry and sulky as the now older Anakin, while McGregor is finally beginning to relax as the mentor who understandably refuses to treat his moody pupil like a grown-up.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: It's a warm, energetic, humorous film, with some excellent ensemble playing; but the cruelty and psychological complexity are lost, and the ensuing tragedy has little resonance.
For those who appreciate dude-speak and bozo humor, this is a very funny film.
Even the eventual universe-shaking shag is an anti-climax, and by the time all hell rips loose just before the abysmally contrived happy ending, you're well past caring.

As a nature doc alone, Encounters at the End of the World would stand as one of the year's best. But it is the people who choose to live and work at the very ends of the Earth that are Herzog's real subject.
movie_title: Encounters at the End of the World (2007)

movie_review_blurb: No one carries a one-liner better than Willis. He's also unusual among Hollywood's Action Men in seeming vulnerable at the same time as being invincible.
The stylish second Bond film From Russia With Love now looks as if it was shot yesterday.
Sadly, the kooky premise of Outlander solidifies quickly into formula: monster is fought, fair maiden won, kingship gained and past errors redeemed with no real surprises along the way.
City Rats is an old Trabant: depressing, prone to stall, its parts not properly welded together.

Though several sequences are gruesome enough to be watched only through splayed fingers, it's no generic horror flick, but one of the most original and audacious British psychological thrillers in a while.
Frequently Asked Questions About Time Travel is, unashamedly, a Mini Cooper of a film: small but nippy.
movie_title: Frequently Asked Questions About Time Travel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Son of Saul understands how many different forces conspired to facilitate it, and moves its endlessly suffering protagonist through as many of them as it possibly can.
Don Verdean is the sort of comedy which presumes its own hilarity long before it gets around to telling any actual jokes, or staging anything that might otherwise be considered funny...
In Youth, the greatest pleasure to be had is to enter into the whole human comedy at all.

Legend offers Hardy the sort of role that an actor can really sink their teeth into. And if the film itself doesn't ever really match the level of effort on hand, it's not for any lack of effort on the endlessly versatile actor's part.
While Victoria is a heist movie of substantial technical merit, it's also just a fine film about Berlin youth culture, and about the singular, seductive joys of being young
It's difficult cinema, absolutely so, but like the most interesting of the difficult movies, it's an eminently memorable watch.

...as a film about rites of passage, specifically those when generally nice if dweeby boys pick up weapons and thus command the attention of hot blondes, it ends up being more than just sophomoric. It's also disquieting, and depressing.
movie_title: Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Room is a truly beautiful work regarding the inextricable bonds between mother and child, and the capacity of the human mind to transcend the body, to continue on when all else appears lost.
To work through the many layers of exposition that The Last Witch Hunter unloads would take longer than this review has to get to why the film isn't very good.
Crimson Peak is hardly the house-of-nightmares feature that may be expected. It is a sadder, more pensive and muted film for its indulgences, more wrenching than frightening.

Whatever it is, here's Pan, the grittier, overexposed origin tale of how Peter Pan came to be Peter Pan that aims to tap into the boundless market of viewers who like when everything is explained in painstaking detail...

It's a high school play-ready version of the riots, a version more focused on outside characters and related inspiring lessons than even the riots themselves, and wears the rosest-colored glasses about the dynamics of the era in which it took place.

The Keeping Room is quick (perhaps too quick), blunt, and brutal, showcasing the escalating horrors of true vulnerability with a grace and minimalism that exceeds the film's modest-bordering-on-muted storytelling.

Scorch at least feels more like a feature-length film than The Maze Runner, which played like a sizzle reel for another film that would eventually follow it. It doesn't shed all the problems of that prior installment, but it's a start.
Even setting aside for a moment that We Are Your Friends feels several years late to its own party, the film is still somehow both cloyingly of-the-moment and instantly obsolete.
The Look of Silence is a breathtaking, haunting piece of documentary cinema, one whose existence is truly baffling and whose images will linger for untold years to come.
The Gift burns slow, far more concerned with character than it is with easy shocks, and it's because of this that when those do come, they hit all the harder. Novel stuff, huh?
The Boy's most disturbing facet is the possibilities it imagines.

Mr. Holmes deconstructs the legend from a perspective so potent that one starts to long for other films about aging heroes that view their subjects in more vulnerable times, and with the lack of sentiment that McKellen finds.
Miles Ahead is a more complicated musician's story, but ultimately it's still a celebration.
Freeheld is a film with grand intentions and little to no idea what to do with them beyond the point of having them.

While Yoga Hosers continues Smith's quest to push himself into increasingly strange and uncomfortable directions as a filmmaker, it's either too derivative or too malformed to work the vast majority of the time.
The Wave is just plausible enough to strike fear into viewers' hearts.

Indignation recalls a crueler time in history, in a manner that offers a strong reminder that melodrama, when executed so well and acted to the nines as this is, isn't always a profanity as it's so often treated.
Genius goes and breaks one of the key tenets of the editorial process: it makes assumptions early and often, largely about how consequential its events seem to be.

Alice Through The Looking Glass is not particularly good. It's a classic case of sequel bloat, a film that seems to exist less because of any extended story it wants or needs to tell than because it must repackage something that was once popular.

Last Days in the Desert accomplishes something that too few modern films about religion even attempt to grasp: faith and mortality are inextricable, from the early sequences of the Bible to the crucifixion and onward.

Dark Horse's primary function is to inspire, and Osmond does this capably; at a fleet 85 mins, the film hardly overstays its welcome, even if it'd hardly be a struggle to spend more time with the boisterous, sometimes toothless members of the syndicate.

The Russos understand how to pace action better than many of their MCU contemporaries, and as such, Civil War moves at a rapid clip despite all the table-setting and it being the lengthiest Marvel film to date at 146 minutes
It's to The Dark Horse's great benefit that this is the rare inspirational true-life story that doesn't shoehorn a fountain of relentless optimism for the future into the proceedings.
The Jungle Book features some of the more astounding visuals in recent film. For a film that's overwhelmingly digital, there's a remarkably tactile quality to so many of the film's setpieces.
The sequel to the faith-based hit loses its heart under several layers of hot-topic opportunism
Eye in the Sky sees, like any good film about warfare, that there are no real victories, and there's no end in sight.

Lo and Behold is no Luddite's screed. With Herzog's signature mix of dry humor and searching interviews, he simply takes our world at face value and uses the Internet to investigate the imperfections of the people who created it.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: An elegant, frustrating, sometimes deeply graceful trip through Los Angeles.
Zootopia might not be the best of Disney's recent in-house movies, but it's easily the most political film the Mouse House has turned out in a good while.
The Invitation is supremely well-crafted.
How To Be Single is an ode to all things young, urban millennial professional, and one thing it gets surprisingly right about the culture is how lonely the spaces between "moments" can be.
Deadpool is very good at what it sets out to do some of the time, and it's going to do exceedingly well because of this.
Creative Control envisions a world in which we can have all of the gratification of interpersonal relationships with little to none of the difficulty. It's an overwhelming, often sad, place.
Any dramatic tension the film establishes is washed away in an ocean of what Demolition Man once called "joy-joy feelings."
Much of Kate Plays Christine is more of a form exercise than it is a documentary portrait, which works to both the film's benefit and detriment.
Carnage Park is an exploitation movie down to its very bones, but writer-director Mickey Keating never really finds a handle on which sort of throwback film he wants to make.
Dark Night approaches the difficult topic of public acts of gun violence in America in a way at once familiar and arguably necessary.
Pixels operates on the Big Bang Theory model of geek comedy, the one that pretends to not be secretly thumbing its nose at the whole thing while benefitting handsomely from it.

But even by the rather lofty modern standards of cynical, pointless cash-ins, Joe Dirt 2 is pronounced, a sequel to a mild hit from nearly 15 years ago that even its most ardent defenders would be hard-pressed to justify

As a relentlessly paced action movie, Furious 7 is an excellent entry for those who would appreciate this sort of thing. As a memorial for one of its own, it's about as affecting as big, loud, ridiculous action movies get.
As "puzzle movies" go, Edge of Tomorrow is one that holds up surprisingly well to scrutiny.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Best of Enemies is effective as both a chronicle of a fraught era in American history and an origin story of the modern state of American televised news journalism.
The Bronze is so satisfied with its own winking crassness that it lets epithets constitute everything it has to say.
Goodbye to Language 3D challenges the very ways in which we watch movies. And that's the point. The things Jean-Luc Godard is able to do with 3D as a medium are astounding.
There are also enough montages that, after a time, you'll be left convinced that in the brave new world of 2015 there is no more filmmaking, only montage.

The film is a whole mess of things, but at heart it's a poignant character study of the divergent ways in which people experience and cope with tragedies, and a powerful reminder that those often have a blanket reach.
movie_title: The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Them (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The Boxtrolls may still make for a better watch than a great many movies spoon-fed to children in the present era, but it's sometimes a little closer to the chaff than a Laika film should be.

For much of its running time, Annabelle is so bereft of ideas for scare tactics that when the doll isn't involved, it's hard to differentiate it from any other domestic horror movie that's ever come out.
Dracula Untold is agreeably silly at points, but that hardly covers for the fact that much of the film's action is visually incomprehensible.
Ultimately, when it comes time to tie the film all together into something memorable, Men, Women & Children offers only its equivalent of a shrugging emoticon in reply.
While the film volleys disturbing statistics throughout, The Hunting Ground keeps the focus exactly where it should be: on the survivors.
Addicted is the kind of film for which the Alan Smithee pseudonym was invented.
Interstellar is a grand gesture in every way. And yet, it's Nolan's most humane film to date.
Horns appears to be of the persuasion that everybody is a liar and inherently evil, and it's a disappointingly one-note approach to a premise that could use a lighter touch.
The Theory of Everything is deftly funny on occasion and lustrously made, key virtues for a film where the plot is largely summarized on Wikipedia already.
Rosewater is at its best when it's less a pick-and-choose historical artifact than an examination of what time in undeserved solitude does to the human mind.
Force Majeure is at once a finely-honed dark comedy and a character study of a family in turmoil,
When the film turns horrifying, The Babadook deftly negotiates the thin line between a well-handled metaphor and a hamfisted one and never strays from the right side of it.
This late-game, tossed-away Fox offering is the very definition of a bargain bin release.
Inherent Vice is a superbly controlled burst of chaos, a madcap masterwork that understands well the value of letting an audience wonder without leading it astray.
Into the Woods sets out to dazzle yet only leaves you wishing for more.
Birdman is an overwhelming experience, a satirical assault on the senses that's hard to believe even as it's seen.
Amy allows for a kinship with a modern fallen star that few films manage, one that is sometimes uncomfortable and often every bit as voyeuristic as the cameras that hounded her in life.
In no small part because of the film's setting, it almost begins to resemble what No Country for Old Men would've looked like if produced by Amblin Entertainment.
Tig isn't exactly groundbreaking. It's more of a well-organized vlog at times than a documentary, but what makes the film work in spite of its episodic simplicity is Notaro.

Like its hard-living protagonists, Ted 2 is an acquired taste, the kind of thing that'll either pull you in with manic camaraderie or push you away with its gleefully poor tastes. Sometimes, though, you just need to guffaw.
San Andreas is essentially the filmic equivalent of Disaster Movie Bingo. Well, not entirely. It doesn't have the dog. But the rest is there.
I'll See You In My Dreams speaks ably to the highs and grave lows of aging and trying to shake life up when it's been comfortable for a very long time.
movie_title: I'll See You in My Dreams (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Tomorrowland is so utterly committed to ol' Uncle Walt's senses of human endeavor and wonder that it becomes a poignant bit of nostalgia.
Heaven Knows What is a disorienting, often brutal, haunting film, as emotionally naked and deeply empathetic a portrait of addiction as modern cinema has seen.
Raiders!, as a documentary, is much like Zala and Strompolos' film in that it's rough around the edges at points, but so utterly sincere that it's hard to deny after a while.
movie_title: Raiders!: The Story of the Greatest Fan Film Ever Made (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Clouds of Sils Maria invites those willing to wander through the minutiae of the obsessive celebrity artist, and that may well be a barrier to entry for those who might land outside that classification.
A triumph of content over form: You could eliminate even more of Going Clear and still have it play like an early contender for the scariest film of 2015.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Get Hard quickly descends from an off-putting comedy of opposites to the kind of movie that time and the changing styles of comedy in the modern age will turn into a relic sooner rather than later.
Films that look and feel like this one have become as perennial as summer action movies, but they're rarely this moving, this resonant, and this flat-out wonderful.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Shallows is an effective B-movie thriller, and this is owed in no small part to Lively, who manages to deliver a woman-in-peril turn that's equal parts magnetic and unexpectedly deadpan.
The Final Girls is the kind of film that could only be made by a true scholar of the form. It's just as funny as it is thoughtful.
Seventh Son doesn't break much new ground, but it's a reasonably entertaining walk through familiar, friendly territory. Every once in a while, that's okay too.
Call Me Lucky is not only a wonderful piece of documentary filmmaking, but an act of substantial bravery as well.
I Smile Back spends most of its 85 minutes working through the paces of every movie about an addict you've ever seen, but it has a secret weapon: Sarah Silverman.
Hellions offers so little beyond a repeated chant and some grotesque visuals that there's not even much to say about it. It's just a copy of a copy of a copy.
Welcome to Leith posits a scenario that could happen in virtually any rust belt town. This is its disquieting power.
Eden is as much about the pains of maturation as it is about the very specific time period and scene in which it occurs.
Cronies is funny and moving in equal doses, a humane film about a handful of guys just trying to get by on the hands they've been dealt by life.
The Diary of a Teenage Girl uses its subject to examine the uncertainty of adolescence with a truly striking candor and realism.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: After a strong, visually striking, resonant start, Lost River quickly descends into a fugue of memorable imagery signifying little and regularly abandons its established motifs for others.

Independence Day was once the enjoyable kind of junk food, but Resurgence is the kind that leaves you walking out in a slack-jawed stupor, wondering why you ever got excited about it in the first place.
Prophet's Prey has few answers, but no shortage of blistering facts, and the sad hope that others can be saved. Eventually.

The Secret Life of Pets isn't anything particularly groundbreaking or ambitious, but it's still a quick, adequately entertaining watch, one that appeals to the basic human impulse to watch animals be funny.
It's when [the film's] mystery comes down to its inevitably messy humanity that the film struggles most conspicuously.
It is a film heavily concerned with the human aspects of artistry, and how even a well-built bank can touch and enrich an inquisitive eye and mind.
Menashe may be a film of understated storytelling and plot, but its pleasures lie primarily in the wonderfully observational approach that Weinstein takes to his protagonist.
Detroit takes an unyielding look at police violence in a way few major Hollywood films have, examining how easily a bad situation can worsen in the wrong, delusional hands.
Girls Trip may deal in broad comedy, but it's an example of broad comedy done well, and delivered by utterly committed performers.
It treats the end of the world as the apocalypse we've always been racing ourselves into, and the one we won't be able to prevent even as we see it coming.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Tour de Pharmacy is a modest success of aggressively stupid comedy.
City of Ghosts is a harrowing account of a Syria that's largely only seen through images of destruction in the West.
For all of the chaos that Okja eventually steers into, its best face is as a simple story of a child on the cusp of young womanhood, trying to save her best friend.
Whose Streets? isn't interested in a both-sides dialogue, and the film hums with its most powerful outrage when it explores the tactics so often used to quell dissent.
Baena's approach is so winkingly bawdy that it can be read either as a goofy tribute to one of the world's oldest sex comedies, or an especially sophomoric take on the same.
This is a commercial for Tupac Shakur the icon, and there's more truth about the man to be found in any one of his songs than this entire two-and-a-half-hour film can muster.
The narrative and tonal gambit the film takes could have been breathtaking if executed successfully, but it only hints at genuine depth in fleeting instances.
First-time director Brian Fee wisely steers the film back to the tone on which it started, one of great affection for big race days and bygone traditions.
[The Hero] is about fifty years and one cancer diagnosis away from retelling any other rote story about a talented-yet-struggling actor hoping to make it in Hollywood.
Beatriz at Dinner makes a melancholic version of the same case that Bill & Ted once did: be excellent to each other. Or there might be consequences.
[Snatched] works less as a high-concept studio comedy than as a take on estranged mother-daughter dynamics, and it's even a little sweet when it smooths off its nastier edges.
Vol. 2 understands well that the action is memorable because of who it's happening to and around, and Gunn never loses that sense of character.
Ponsoldt and Eggers' screenplay yields a heavy-handed take on web titans and the doublespeak of Internet buzzwords, and struggles to generate intrigue from either.
[The film] confronts the terror of a world that remains mysterious even after every map has been drawn and every foot of land trod upon.
The CGI is still incomprehensible, the characters are still paper-thin, and it's a movie that even manages to reduce magic itself to the trickery of ancient machines.
Even as Fate has its fun and chases its highs (a few of which are pretty satisfying), it's hard to shake the growing sensation that the bloom might be coming off the rose.
Good Time observes something primal about the worlds that exist beneath the worlds in which so many other movies are made and viewed.
From its lurid early scenes onward, Bushwick walks a razor-thin line between Carpenter-esque political nihilism and outright exploitation.
The Death Cure feels unusually anticlimactic for a film that's pretty much all climax.
Winston and Henson manage to bring a depth to their relationship that the bone-stiff screenplay never truly does.
If the sum of the film never rises to the highs of some of its most moving parts, those parts are nevertheless worth attention on their own.
It's the kind of film that sets up a compelling sandbox in which to play, and then smashes gracelessly through it, cackling all the while.
Phantom Thread may be modestly subdued in the presentation of its emotions, but they're omnipresent, hanging like a haze over every scene and every terse exchange of dialogue.
By the film's end you may well find yourself shocked that both men allowed the directorial duo to keep filming for as long as they did.
There's a sharp meditation on law and revolution within Israel, but it never fully surfaces, and it leaves a general impression of disappointment after a time.
Three Billboards may be a film chiefly concerned with rage, and pain, but it's also one of the best dark comedies of recent vintage, and one of the better dramas as well.
[Trier] finds moments of quiet horror, externalizing Thelma's turmoil in ways both blunt and memorably disturbing.
While Logan Lucky gives off the impression of a shaggy character-based comedy, such an assessment shortchanges how deliriously clever it is.
It's a redemption tale, but one where forgiveness and vengeance and understanding alike are achieved via the edges of so many sharpened swords.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Even the destruction, the ostensible reason for the film's whole existence, is surprisingly dull.
In its way, 78/52 is also a spiritual tribute to the obsession that Hitchcock himself brought to the famed sequence.
The storytelling is episodic by design, and Lynch ably finds the ache and confusion in the most minute deviations from Lucky's existential patterns.
This is a film of rare joy, even in its more unsparing moments, and the kind of film that should be seen by anybody who loves movies.
While the Mulleavys have a distinct command of tone and texture, the film is more a collage of striking images than any kind of a cogent whole built from them.
It's less the ribald ripped-from-the-headlines commentary it aspires to be than a cynically breezy take on an ugly, unduly buried chapter of American history.
This might be auteur cinema, but it's also auteur cinema that exists to tear that idea to shreds and dissect its most fragile inner parts.
Goon: Last of the Enforcers often feels far more like a stock sports film than its predecessor, and that's what ultimately turns it into a highly underwhelming follow-up.
Death Note carries a weirdly perfunctory air about itself throughout, even as the bodies begin to fall closer and closer to its main duo.
There's nothing left to Jigsaw but to wait on the next gory death, and then reset for the next. It's a cinematic funhouse of viscera to be immediately discarded after viewing.
[It's] built on an ingenious premise, and if McDowell occasionally falters in how he chooses to explore its boundaries, it's still an inquisitive piece of existential sci-fi.
Your Name is the kind of film that's all the more striking for how easily it could have gone awry, but Shinkai has accomplished something unique and genuinely special here.
Return of Xander Cage has no regard for the existence of "the top," so there's no time to care about going over it.
It's the rare Hollywood movie that'll leave you wishing three-hour cuts were still in fashion at the studio level, just to see this as it could've been.
Passengers starts to more resemble a ridiculous fake movie inside of a Hollywood satire than a thought-though science fiction thriller.
Collateral Beauty is a film that's virtually impossible to take seriously, despite dealing with the most personal kind of thematic material.
It's of the season, it's relentlessly bawdy, and it's a showcase for talented comedians doing what they can to make an impression in the often limited time they get.
It's a traditional kind of Disney movie, a crowd pleaser with a few earworms on its soundtrack and an endearing pair of mismatched leads on an impeccably animated adventure.
The Edge of Seventeen has more than enough earnestness of heart to make up for its structural shortcomings. It's a teen film with an uncommonly honest ear for interactions.
Into the Inferno feels unusually episodic by Herzog's typically cohesive standards.

Shin Godzilla is a true-blue Godzilla movie, and suggests that perhaps Toho has found its best way into a new era, and might have the chance to continue to offer cautionary warnings for generations to come.
It's a film of unforgettable images, but one that finds purpose within them, a film that understands the value of sensation and texture and place no matter where it wanders.
After establishing an engaging tone early on, Power Rangers descends into familiarity after a while, and it's a mild (if expected) letdown.

Snowden is a film of sincere outrage, even when it strains to articulate that outrage in a less from-the-headlines manner, and a reminder that right now, somewhere else in the world, the real Edward Snowden is still waiting to return home.
The Lure somehow manages to seamlessly assemble a film equal parts hilarious, affecting, and grisly while trading and warping aesthetics and tones by the scene.
Sully could have very easily been a film about a tragic plane crash, and Eastwood invites audiences to simply stop and consider the miracle for a while longer.
The Light Between Oceans is an effective melodrama, but the lingering sensation the film leaves after its end is that it might have been much more.
Mechanic: Resurrection plays in an uncommonly generic key, and the film only makes intermittent attempts to enliven the proceedings.
The Hollars deals in weighty personal tragedies, and yet neither the treacly, offbeat humor nor the moments of more straightforward pathos tend to work for any real length of time.
Like the studio's previous films, Kubo dares to dream that entertainment aimed at a younger audience can hold the depth and intelligence of any other substantial piece of filmmaking.
As both an utterly mad true story and as a document of the boundless reach of the cinema across borders and cultures and even ideologies, The Lovers and the Despot is wild, valuable viewing for all.

After a while, even Ayer's wildest stylistic choices settle down into DC Films' house style: the muted tones and industrial black/blue that Zack Snyder used to build America's visually dullest franchise of the moment.

To pick a fight with a filmmaker like Dinesh D'Souza, or a film like Hillary's America: The Secret History of the Democratic Party, is to give the two respective burning trash fires more credit than either warrants.
movie_title: Hillary's America: The Secret History of the Democratic Party (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There's a lot of joy to go around in Eight Days a Week, to such a degree that the film might have verged on feeling like a puff piece, were it not about perhaps the only rock band that's ever wholly justified the endless time spent fixated upon it.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Life, Animated doesn't aim for "awareness" so much as a more honest, comprehensive understanding of autism as a shifting thing particular to each person affected. It's a warmly empathetic documentary.
Dayveon's muted, largely allusive storytelling takes a backseat to tone and place throughout, and Abbasi demonstrates an assured command of both.
Landline immerses itself in the misunderstandings and mixed signals of relationships, and Robespierre and Elisabeth Holm's screenplay races from scene to scene.
For a sequel in which many familiar faces and locations are reprised, T2 Trainspotting is unusually candid about the hazards of looking backwards for too long, especially by sequel standards.
One of the most transgressive things about Raw is how Ducournau keeps the focus on the unjust judgment of others, rather than the shame Justine internalizes throughout.
It understands the appeal of these movies as a reminder of humanity's relative insignificance in the face of horrors it can't possibly comprehend.
It's a brief film, clocking in at barely 70 minutes, but Zucchini is also far more heartfelt and resonant than so many cacophonous family films.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There's little to Fist Fight that distinguishes itself, and it's the kind of comedy that's good for the odd laugh every few minutes, but also dissipates from memory almost as soon as it ends.
Chapter 2 is a hyper-violent piece of pulp action cinema through and through, but it's also an exemplar of how to make such a film with style and intelligence.
Imperial Dreams makes a modest, sincere case for the seeming futility of a post-jail existence.
Given the sheer volume of jokes on hand, it's impressive how often LEGO Batman successfully lands its punchlines.

Captain Fantastic loses its intriguing premise in a muddle of ideas about the redemptive power of family and the right of all people to live as they please. It's a disappointing film, a strangely unintelligent handling of an intelligent idea.
An Inconvenient Sequel will be denigrated for its polemics, but it's less an attack on big business than a call for a rational assessment of proven facts.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Guadagnino's film is one of swooning sentiment, but it never once cheapens or diminishes the rich emotion of its story for extraneous impact.
Rees broadens her focus on race here and communicates something that's initially familiar and eventually haunting about the cyclical nature of ignorance and oppression.
Brigsby Bear offers a touching and daringly unconventional reminder of how no approach to filmmaking is inherently bad with the right mind at the helm.
It's a quiet, delicate film, one aching with regret and loss, an impressionistic approach to death that eventually reveals itself as a touching elegy for the passage of time.
Peele is sharply perceptive about how racism is so often diminished even by people who allegedly know better, and it's a conceit that serves Get Out incredibly well.
The key to Nobody Speak emerges in the candid interviews, which reveal how unnecessary the entire case probably was at the start, and how necessary it became.
movie_title: Nobody Speak: Trials of the Free Press (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The same could be said of XX at large; most [of the shorts] have some interesting ideas, but none of them stand out in any kind of lingering way.
Those willing to let Ellison walk them through his 93-minute nightmare will find something challenging, revolting, and eminently watchable.
While James L. Brooks is a good point of comparison, as is producer Judd Apatow's talky, hangout-centric approach, Showalter has made something unique and wonderful here.

movie_title: A Bottle in the Gaza Sea (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Spectacular and emotionally riveting re-creation of one family's nightmarish ordeal while vacationing in Thailand during the historic 2004 tsunami is the kind of classy disaster pic that should attract broad audiences.
art-house fans who do venture forth into the grim but incredibly poignant  Amour  will be richly rewarded.

Prospects for a drama about the relationship between a homeless fighter and legless woman seem dim indeed, but Jacques Audiard shows he can turn seemingly impossible material into full-blown entertainment. Critics and the usual audiences should respond.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: As fascinating as it is provocative about aspects of evil, guilt, denial, heredity and repentance, this Israeli/German co-production offers much to think about.

A must-see documentary about the questionable laws, enforcement and justice at work in Israel's occupied zones, where an apparent double standard are imposed on the densely packed Palestinian occupants.

Burn is not just a celebration of these wonderful, involving fighters of fires and so much more that threatens survival. It is also a tribute to the decent working class and firefighters everywhere who impact so many lives.
Concerned citizens who also value glossy, high-end, high-minded docs will feel rewarded, if not a bit more frustrated by an epidemic of denial fueled by voices from the right.
Beautifully acted and lush look at a real-life court threesome in Denmark at the end of the 18th century indeed pleases.
One of the strongest adult dramas to come out of Hollywood in a long time.

This assured look at a renegade young brother/trashy older sister duo in a dreary apartment complex on a barren Swiss valley plain dominated by a posh ski resort above underscores the divide between the "have-nots" and the vacationing "haves."
Sprawling crime drama about a high-achieving young Parisian lawyer forced to dump a seemingly picture-perfect life and go on the run is a suspenseful journey with emotional detours.

Well-done, well-meaning but predictable, by-the-familiar-numbers drama about two working single mothers who go activist to buck the public-school bureaucracy and create a better learning institution for their own and other urban kids.
Less a luxurious cinematic meal than a generous spread of snippets and tidbits, this feast for foodies features ten mostly European-based Michelin-awarded chefs.
movie_title: Drei Sterne - Die Köche und die Sterne (Three Stars) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Nice youth pic about an early-'90s high-school freshman misfit benefits from an avalanche of period rock hits and pleasing performances.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Fun, often droll crime thriller about a grungy slob of a hit man given an assignment in the remote, snowy Carpathian Mountains provides a nifty ride for both more demanding audiences and the usual suspects looking for raunchiness.
Juicy, smart, engrossing financial thriller boasts assets aplenty in its portfolio.

This familiar but supremely well-told and produced tale of the unlikely rise of an Aboriginal female pop group in the Vietnam War-era is feel-good entertainment at its best. Performances, solid script and great music all hit the high notes.
Delightful, fanciful comedy is given much added life by performances from a strong cast, pungent dialogue and inspired production design.
Often amusing silent black-and-white take on the classic "Snow White" tale impresses not much beyond being another visually impactful homage to period silents.
Excellent, well-paced drama boasting Robert Redford as director and lead. Terrific cast and writing fortify this cat-and-mouse chase through a web of revelations.
Impressive debut from New Zealand-born Scott Walker is told with style and panache. Strong performances, fevered pacing and immersive location lensing are big pluses pushing this from "B" pic to A-.

Terrific dramatization of Apple founder Steve Jobs' rise from inspired, art-inclined hippie to corporate mogul and King of Cool delivers "Mac"-nificently and should gratify everyone from die-hard geeks to gawkers curious about entrepreneurial success.
Legrand pays homage to this talent by packaging him with a fine script, a strong supporting cast and a rich production that make this fraught wine world both thrilling and chilling.
Here, empowered by Danny Strong's smart, encyclopedic screenplay, Daniels tackles both a bigger canvas and cast and manages the challenge with consummate skill.
For kids, Percy and pals are good company and the special effects are often fresh and eye-popping. There are further benefits for the few older fans on hand who love mythology.
In a World... is mild entertainment that provides a credible look inside the trailer voice world and its actor populace that makes do on the fringe of Hollywood and the big time.

Perfectly cast, acutely rendered drama based on the true story of accidental porn sensation Linda Lovelace and her abusive manager/husband delivers big-time as it captures recognizable characters from the seedy '70s.
All performances register high, including Lohan and her husky voice, but Deen, even inhabiting a must-hate character, truly impresses as an actor who "gets" the craft and its nuances.

But the family drama that simmers beneath is really what intrigues: the questionable quality of her parents' marriage and the disturbing truths that hint at her father's harsh, unloving behavior towards her.

Also a poignant consideration of traditional ways and so-called "progress" touted to improve things, Terraferma is a nostalgic type of high-quality foreign drama that, in the old days, would have "stuck" on screens or become classic in some sense.
Once again, Allen corrals an impeccable cast and often delicious scenery to ease this uneven journey for filmgoers. Loyal Allen fans, also lured by the plot's Madoff angle, will be onboard.

Very sloppy drama about a young American drug tourist in Chile determined to find a mescaline-rich cactus in the country's remote north offers nothing beyond beach and desert scenery and plenty of totally gratuitous Gaby Hoffmann nudity.
The Hunt is beautifully shot and performed. But gritty, immersive Dogme it is not.

Four wine-obsessed guys prepare for the grueling Master Sommelier Exam in this highly entertaining doc, which gives a taste not just of that grape profession, but also of male bonding and the obsessive drive for perfection and success.

Veteran German director Margarethe von Trotta has perhaps her strongest film to date with Hannah Arendt, yet another of her works about historically important women. Also notable is the superb cast led by Barbara Sukowa.

Israel's official submission for Oscar's 2012 Best Foreign Language Film is a stunning melodrama centered on an ultra-Orthodox Jewish community and prospects for a tragedy-fueled arranged marriage between a teen and older man.
State 194 delivers hope, frustration and more evidence that politics should not be left just to politicians.

Nifty little genre gem with its share of surprises has three damsel campers in distress on an isolated island they didn't know they'd be sharing with three hunters back from overseas battle and with too much fight left in them.
Music-filled drama amounts to several promises unfulfilled except for some solid performances and a terrific soundtrack of Buckley songs, both actual and skillfully recreated.
Directing partners Scott McGehee and David Siegel go more mainstream and downstream with this modern-day, loose riff on Henry James' late-19th-century novel.
Ugly Americans and not so pretty Chinese dominate this cheesy doc about a cheesy group of L.A. filmmakers trying to make a cheesy film in China with Chinese backing.
Dense, ambitious, consistently interesting but sometimes murky cross-cultural, cross-continental exploration of the roots of extremism, prejudice and revenge.

Delicious, intriguing and addictive exposé of the creative-writing process and middle-class dysfunction. Wry humor and mystery also bring alive what might be acclaimed filmmaker François Ozon's most accomplished and unpredictable work to date.
As gorgeous as it is leisurely and contemplative, this appropriately magnificent and impressionistic portrait of the elderly Pierre-Auguste Renoir in 1915 will delight art-house fans.
Suspense is anemic in this dark hospital drama about a resident getting too intensive in his care for an attractive patient.
The Tower offers solid performances and stories that hold interest, but its look is more that of TV movie than atmospheric evocation of a dreary historic period.
Some fans of the late Robin Williams may emerge to patronize this charmless, low-ball, low-wattage entry.
Warm, emotionally effective film for dog lovers of all ages traces the many lives of one canine on its soul's journey through different bodies, breeds, generations and owners.
A classic whodunit with Asghar Farhadi's characteristically impeccable plotting and buildup of suspense.
Suspenseful zigzagging adventure drama has a top-of-his-game Matthew McConaughey as a wired 1980s Reno mining company dreamer salivating for and maybe getting the big strike.
[P]art Sirkian melodrama, part Hitchcock-lite [...] a career high for Spanish maestro Pedro Almodóvar.
This only-in-America tale is a cinematic Big Mac of classy, easily digestible entertainment, topped by Michael Keaton's thrilling performance.
Scores on the all-important war, home and entertainment fronts, while garnering extra points for the new technology involved.
With its story of backstage dramas going haywire, Ovation, yet another light comedy trifle from [the] notably prolific... Henry Jaglom, won't get one from this seat.
Sour-turned-sweet comedy-drama about a sour-turned-almost-sweet retired curmudgeon in terminal grief over his deceased wife blossoms into an unexpected cinematic gem.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's impossible to imagine how Denial could have been better cast, written or fortuitously blessed with such potent subjects as anti-Semitism and the Holocaust.

This inspiring doc, shot through a rose-colored lens of optimism, provides a lightweight insiders' look at six recent college grads, most newly arrived in Detroit to work at rising startups or grow their own.
This well-made drama borrows a little-known sliver of history concerning Denmark's post-war mistreatment of young German POWs forced to defuse and extract land mines.
[Oliver Stone] combin[es] skill and provocation with a passion to entertain in this riveting portrait of young American fugitive Edward Snowden.
A comforting throwback to the studio's days of dependable family fare.
Falls short of a four-star cinematic experience.
Has an authentic exterior but too little beneath the surface.
Bold, beautiful and entirely engaging fictional love story.
Don't Think Twice is a smart, engaging, hugely entertaining ride that rewards indie fans appreciative of solid comedy and fine craftsmanship.
An unfortunate mash-up of ambiguities, inauthenticity and ill-conceived performances is the real crime in this true-crime-based exposé.
Mostly engaging, mostly talking-heads documentary.
Access to a subject is everything in a doc, and filmmakers Josh Kriegman and Elyse Steinberg got it in spades with Weiner.
Money Monster boasts nary an authentically surprising, witty or emotional moment.
Entertaining, informative and beautifully rendered documentary homage to the late-20th-century artist [Eva Hesse].
The film, requiring a lot of attention, is ultimately highly satisfying.
movie_title: The People vs. Fritz Bauer (Der Staat Gegen Fritz Bauer) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: So Chinese that American fans of the action genre may resist.
Has special relevance in today's lying times.
Throws little light on the endless Israeli-Palestinian conflict but stuns as a contrast to today's shrill leaders.
Eye-pleasing, intelligent dive into the relationship dilemmas of some upscale Brooklyn Millennials stays afloat with impressive cast and some will they/won't they tension.
An audience pleaser for viewers of all persuasions who value honesty and a job well done.
Another powerful, superbly performed contemporary drama from Ziad Doueiri.
Delivers simple pleasures amidst wartime realities.
movie_title: The Two of Us (Le vieil homme et l'enfant) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: [A] dazzling cinematic tour de force.
As quirky as it is charming.
movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: [P]arents will appreciate the film's many strong points and spirit while getting immense pleasure from just watching their kids' pleasure.
[Director Dan] Gilroy goes bigger and better with a film deserving a long life at the box office.
A perfect film of its kind.
Quality-seeking recruits also out for old-fashioned movie entertainment will get in line.
Hits career high points for both star Woody Harrelson and director Rob Reiner.
The Divine Order is intelligent fun but functions on another level.
Offered as a warm-hearted dog yarn, this gentle but tendentious fact-based family drama goes astray into agitprop for family and Christian values.
Should prove a winner among sports fans and all those who value excellence and achievement.
So determined to please, it does.
Superb performances, authentic settings and effective story structure all heighten involvement.
Preposterous genre stew with wacky plot spasms and underdeveloped characters populating a family yarn of sorts about an 11-year-old genius' mother-driven vengeance plan.
A worthy addition to the considerable canon of films about the great statesman.
The Journey looms a best-bet package for a predictable slice among serious filmgoers.
Solid work and gripping drama are expected and again delivered with writer-director Oren Moverman's latest.
This chef profile is magnificent in both style and substance and perfectly suits its subject, now living reclusively in Mexico after reigning atop the food world for decades.
Like Dickinson's poetry, is alive, accessible and urgent.
Another major achievement from François Ozon.
Rich, often surprising and touching doc about the Lower East Side's storied matzo factory.
movie_title: Streit's: Matzo And The American Dream (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This pummeling drama about a self-absorbed, alcoholic actress who fails as a wife and mother is all about the intense performance of star Paprika Steen. A bonanza to be devoured by students/practitioners/fans of the thesp trade.
Patient audiences who value quality films expertly played and with terrific craftsmanship throughout [...] will behold a treat.
[Cheadle] chews the role with intensity, but so determined an effort doesn't quite compensate for obvious budget constraints, a dubious structure and problematic screen hero.
Beautifully shot, feverishly edited and also benefiting from the right score and authentic locations, Hyena is that kind of ugly film that refuses to let you turn away.
Wobbly in its intentions to deliver both heist-heavy suspense, sociological realism and a touching family drama.
Always absorbing and gripping.
Blessed with heaps of talent behind and in front of the camera.
Gloriously shot, finely acted.
Ferrara gives a nice flow to this far-from-nice ordeal.
This close-up, contemporary look inside a super-secretive Oxford University dining society of ostensible gentlemen sparkles with rapid-fire dialogue and outrageous behavior.
3 Hearts just doesn't make sense-either as story or career move.
Disney's live-action version of the familiar fairytale boasts a glittery cast, but the overwhelming production design eats its own scenery.
All in all, October Gale is nice work, but that doesn't always cut it these days.
The pleasures in this doc about Jewish delicatessens are piled high as the iconic mile-high pastrami on rye.
The shock, horror and occasional levity of the doc aside, Merchants of Doubt reminds us how maddening it is what money can do to ruin things.
[1971] benefits mightily from superb re-enactments, the palpable integrity of its activist band of break-in artists, and some Rififi-like suspenseful moments.
Too familiar by half to be indie/arty/edgy and too anemic by another half to surface as mainstream/commercial.
Awash in pills, wind chimes and ugly vibes, the film has a ton of producers credited, suggesting too many cooks might have spoiled this Cake.
[A] beautifully shot, wrenching and suspenseful drama.
In the spirit of the best Disney classics, Paddington is one for the ages and all ages.
Smart, informative investigation ... also affords a fascinating look at the history of Chinese-Americans and their successful assimilation into our society.
Viewers aged ten or under can safely enter this latest Museum and have a good time. But those older had best be toting a tot or two.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: [If You Don't, I Will is] a disappointing, too-lean portrait of a marriage.
[Antarctica: A Year On Ice] is not your usual travelogue, but a surprising exploration of the human soul and human needs.
The Imitation Game is a rich production ... that amounts to an engaging, even mesmerizing rendering of one of history's most important events.
Grey and grim, this really isn't kids' stuff, but the kids won't be deterred.
It's the presence of the unflagging, always compelling [Catherine] Deneuve [...] that is the added value here.
movie_title: In the Name of My Daughter (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Look for the kind of critical support and word of mouth that sparks impressive art-house traffic.
This is a work many cuts above the norm, with the leads resonating on several levels and supporting talent, settings and period as authentic as Marseillaise bouillabaisse.
Unconventional but fully fleshed-out and adoring (but not too adoring) portrait of brilliant Beach Boys leader Brian Wilson and his personal ups and downs.
Overall, this merry mash-up of AARP members and tech-savvy carefree hipsters is fun and entertaining in a determinedly non-groundbreaking way.
Marguerite will enchant quality-seeking viewers appreciative of originality, spectacle and serious music.
Norway's 2015 Oscar entry for Best Foreign Language Film didn't land the nom but lands solidly as an engrossing genre film.
A genuinely entertaining package.
Fun fare for foodies, especially those with a taste for classic French cuisine and nostalgia for the posh French restaurants that once dominated the culinary scene.
Not quite smart, but a pleasing enough diversion within its sweet, sunny, non-threatening narrow confines for a narrow target.
Vulgar, occasionally funny cinematic splatter, with Tina Fey and Amy Poehler doing broad, tacky strokes as two sisters who are back in their hometown raising hell.
Often hilarious and perfectly cast take on the 2008 housing bubble burst.
Good-spirited, provocative and satisfying look at the great Hollywood screenwriter Dalton Trumbo.
Flirting, skullduggery and deep cynicism-along with painful truisms-course through this fast and flashy amusement.
Delivers to both food snobs and fast-foodies who can digest smart entertainment.
Fans of Laurie Anderson will enjoy her intimate exploration of love, grief, mortality, childhood, words, art, personal philosophy and on and on in Heart of a Dog.
Reveals the obvious, but sometimes interestingly.
The film is beautifully acted and well-paced, even as it unravels onto many paths.
Denis Villeneuve delivers an appropriately loud, jumpy, energy-driven take on this country's seemingly hopeless struggle to end Mexico's drug war.
A perfect fit for more serious audiences, thanks to solid work on both sides of the camera.
This miniature of a family in crisis [...] is richly rewarding, even without fiery battles, lavish set-pieces or high drama.
There's just too much déja vu at play on this court.
Paulette offers a heap of laughs and ultimately delights like a shelf of colorful fresh pastries.
Best of Enemies is, in the truest sense, a delicious entertainment of real-life deep-seeded resentments perfect for any size screen.
It's a vanity production in which only the dog should be vain.
Finely acted, directed and shot, Max is rewarding all around.
If not exactly offering nonstop suspense, Spy provides nonstop laughs and chuckles.
There's enough spectacle and entertainment onscreen to nudge the satisfaction needle in the right direction.

Must-see documentary teeming with commentary largely from digital-savvy top industry players follows theatrical film's journey from celluloid origins to late 20th-century digital innovations through to the triumphant digital changeover in progress.
Drama of a female teen and her gang in a tough Paris project delivers some fine acting but is wobbly in its story of the young heroine's sad journey into an ugly early adulthood.
Exceptionally well-made and emotionally riveting documentary...A celebration of the very best in human nature and a trove of delightful, thrilling and even suspenseful moments.

So-so documentary about filmmaker Michel Gondry's gregarious elderly aunt and her reminiscences of family and long years teaching kids in rural France. Clearly a joy for nephew Gondry and his aunt, but maybe this should have been kept en famille.
Award-winning playwright Conor McPherson delivers a beautiful, even believable ghost drama that enraptures on many levels.

Interesting if not profound doc that wrangles many of the usual suspects who have played the Hollywood screenwriting game and often triumphed. Breezy fun for film buffs and aspiring writers eyeing that studio brass ring.
Compelling documentary featuring a remarkably appealing transsexual high-school star quarterback and her adopted, brain-damaged brother who learns he's the grandson of Orson Welles and Rita Hayworth.
This so-so doc about yet another dysfunctional middle-class New York Jewish family disintegrating in a recent bygone era is definitely best suited to home viewing.
Handsome, well-done if too familiar look at the romantic and professional games played by upscale twentysomething Manhattan professionals working pre-recession.
Made-for-TV Brit crime-drama trilogy set against the true-life search for "The Yorkshire Ripper" falls short of its many impressive parts.
Nice coming-of-age doc about an African-American teen who shares a Brooklyn brownstone with the white Jewish lesbian parents who adopted her and two adopted siblings.
Fact-based drama about a father's fight to find a cure for his children's debilitating disease is intelligent and involving.
...exuberant but unfocused drama about a recent French news story that caused a sensation before being exposed as bogus. Jewish-themed elements may also help fill seats.
movie_title: The Girl on the Train (La Fille du RER) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Well-made, terrifically acted biopic about the Chicago Chess Brothers and their legendary Chess label and artists who propelled blues into a new genre called rock 'n' roll. A cornucopia of great music, though some cinematic notes are off-key.
Usually more laid-back chaps, Sherlock Holmes and sidekick Watson are now action heroes in a tale stripped of modulations, intelligence and finesse.
Amusing black comedy about an avenging wife features a strong cast directed by Cheryl Hines.

Rock-filled ensemble comedy inspired by the rogue broadcasts of rock hits from North Sea ships in the '60s runs seriously aground from so much lightweight cargo and an apocalyptic ending pirated from action-adventure.
The unsubtle approach to a lead character--a crude, motormouth Hollywood talent agent--sinks this otherwise often watchable comedic drama about a show-biz fish out of water in quaintest Guatemala.
Small-scale but absorbing drama from Chile about an upper-middle-class family and their territorial maid.
Director Davidson still shines with this modest production.
Impressive production and performances outweigh ambiguities in this low-budget Holocaust-themed contemporary drama...
Docu-like film based on exploits of an actual Belfast hood turned informer against IRA terrorists is an explosive cinematic experience.
Lame horror entry about a woman who gives birth to a literal little monster won't scare up the bucks, in spite of post-fest hype.
This wonderful doc about radio and TV icon Gertrude Berg is a cornucopia of nostalgia for viewers of a certain age.
Perfect casting and all-around craftsmanship make this delightful, music-fueled contemporary rumination on a big-city romance a big summer surprise.
Amusing black comedy about an avenging wife features a strong cast directed by Cheryl Hines.
This deliciously perverse, splashy, lively collage of the high-end contemporary London art scene provides a guilty pleasure to students of sex, greed and manipulation. Aesthetics is beside the point.

So-so, light tale of a successful New York architect who endangers his comfortable, conventional life to navel-gaze and write a play provides some moments for the always watchable Timothy Hutton. But there's not much else to watch.

Hilarious, often silly French hit is the latest in a franchise that spoofs the James Bond brand, in the spirit of "Get Smart" and the Pink Panther films. The Yank audience is out there, but can it be uncovered?
movie_title: OSS 117: Rio ne répond plus (Lost in Rio) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Terrific Algerian/French drama, set against the decades-long fight for Algerian independence from France, follows the plight of three brothers who embody different commitments to this nationalistic cause and face different consequences.

Sincere, handsomely produced rendition of real-life encounter...amounts to an engaging drama seasoned by a dollop of soft-core titillation. History buffs, especially, among the upscale art-house crowd won't be disappointed.
Quote not available.
movie_title: Copper Mountain: A Club Med Experience (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A slight and messy effort from two German filmmakers that adds nothing to our understanding of the Holocaust.
Unblinking look at an haute bourgeoise French wife who dumps her workaholic husband to embark full-time on a passionate affair with the couple's Spanish contractor is as believable as it is tragic.

Riveting performance from James Franco dominates as iconic Beat Generation poet Allen Ginsberg does battle with intrusive animation and static talking-head scenes. There's no rhyme nor reason for this ill-conceived concept.
Every bit as glam, entertaining, punchy and timely as the original.
Heartfelt, feel-good doc about France's coveted competition to anoint the country's highest honor in patisserie delivers huge servings of emotionally wrenching drama and delicious visuals.

Slight but nuanced tale of two working-class New York couples beset by inner (albeit benign) demons is ignited by nice writing and acting, most notably from infallible Oscar winner Philip Seymour Hoffman, here making his feature directorial debut.

...every bit as engaging as its just-released, high-performing predecessor. Vincent Cassel's remarkable performance and action-packed filmmaking assure impressive numbers on specialized screens and maybe beyond.
...the light cinematic menu served here offers little more than a confusing pot au feu of guests and their problems.
movie_title: Change of Plans (Le Code a Changé) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: ...Another visual triumph from the celebrated Chinese director, but quirky eye candy of superficial comic-book proportions can go only so far with art-house crowds.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The kid's not all right in this appealing high-concept and surprisingly affecting romantic drama about a married gay couple who get a nasty surprise after believing they've adopted an ideal child.
Fact-based, revenge-fueled tale of a female teen's determination to expose a particularly virulent branch of the Sicilian Mafia is a worthy but modest effort.

With minimal means achieving maximum cinematic effect, debuting British feature director J Blakeson delivers a chilling, surprising kidnapping thriller that is as raw as it is funny and engages all the way through to its clever ending.

Teeming with commentary from well-known celebrities, this exceptional doc about Hugh Hefner and the ascent of liberalism celebrates both the iconic Playboy founder and the receding of taboos and prejudice over the past half-century.
movie_title: Hugh Hefner: Playboy, Activist and Rebel (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Potentially delicious tale of flamboyant Upper East Side walker on the skids and the innocent young aspiring writer he wrangles as a roommate is too broadly played and unfocused to click.

Documentary loaded with talking-head interviews with some of foreign and American indie cinema's more intriguing living directors is more superficially diverting than profoundly informative, but with a flurry of classic clips to break up the static, it's
Great filmmaking and acting throughout, especially from returning leads Noomi Rapace and Michael Nyqvist.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Outstanding, emotionally and visually rich documentary about the spontaneous 1969 Stonewall Inn riots that gave birth to and fueled the gay-rights movement comes out contemporaneously with the annual late-June global gay-pride celebrations that followed S
Effortless performances and nice Provençal backdrop make this easily digested cinematic comfort food.
movie_title: Let it Rain (Parlez-moi de la pluie) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Terrific documentary about the deserved crash and subsequent rise to cultdom of the awful, no-budget, sort-of horror film Troll 2.
An idealistic East Coast film school grad encounters the L.A. porn business in this witless low-budget comedy. More exit-rated than X-rated, it's pretty limp.

This latest, more mature installment in the "prince" of franchises should prove to be one of the strongest, as better plotting, pacing, effects and always delicious Brit cast tempt more elders to join the kid masses.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This wonderful doc about radio and TV icon Gertrude Berg is a cornucopia of nostalgia for viewers of a certain age, but Berg's signature Molly Goldberg character lacks "I Love Lucy" legs.

Silly romantic comedy about a very proper top Parisian criminal lawyer on a case in Monaco where he falls for a trashy local eludes both truths and justice to its audience. Some pretty Monegasque scenery and a cameo from acting vet Stéphane Audran are no
movie_title: La Fille de Monaco (The Girl from Monaco) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Delightful, involving doc about an unlikely couple who became pioneer contemporary art collectors with working-class salaries.

Drama about a French Jewish family's suffering, secrets, and denials regarding Nazi persecution during the French Occupation is an often disorienting collage of memory shards. But the legendary Jeanne Moreau and other excellent cast help hold interest.

Sunny, wholesome, exuberant third installment of Disney's teen musical franchise is strictly for the kids. It's overdone in a comforting old Hollywood-meets-Bollywood way designed for the teen-and-younger demographic.
Ultimately, Stranded is about good people surviving with dignity and decency through the worst that can be imagined. Could there be a more appropriate film for the times we live in now?
movie_title: Stranded: I Have Come from a Plane That Crashed on the Mountains (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Give W. a W for "wonderful," B for "balance," and A for excellence in those things that add up to terrific filmed entertainment. Brolin's Dubya, Stone's direction, and Weiser's script nail it, with invaluable support from others both above and below-the-l

This inventive, charming picture-perfect picaresque tale of an ambitious young Czech rascal scrambling in the pre-Nazi and wartime eras marks a welcome and victorious return for Jiri Menzel, whose last major conquest was his 1967 Oscar-winning debut, C
movie_title: I Served the King of England (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Dud drama about a med-school failure from L.A. who finds himself amidst pot-growing hippies in a remote corner of the eponymous "Lost Coast" county.
There's warmth aplenty in Rachel Getting Married, and a little anarchy. But it's the authenticity that's lacking.
Delivers to diehard fans of both the veteran's films and The Travel Channel.
This latest skewering of the privileged, tragically flawed and selfishly driven makes it clear that there is no other filmmaker to better tell The Eliot Spitzer Story.
movie_title: La Fille Coupée en Deux (The Girl Cut in Two) (A Girl Cut in Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Mumblecore to the core--a loose, quirky, minimal indie.
movie_title: In Search of a Midnight Kiss (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A gripping, beautifully written drama suffused with authenticity.
Will send most viewers running, not to war protests, but to Woodstock '69 DVDs or rentals.
While arousing trepidations, this latest entry is oft-times digestible, thanks largely to its juicy subject.
A riveting portrait of the unusually obsessed, gifted, charismatic and downright gutsy Petit.
A fatally fractured, disconnected mosaic of unappealing, marginal Hollywood types haphazardly interconnecting.
There's much material here and it is brilliantly structured.
A delicious outpouring of upper-crust malevolence, hovering cynicism and ever-deepening ambivalence that zigzags dizzyingly among its many characters, locations and plot turns.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: False, forced, familiar and often vulgar, especially in its language and depiction of certain characters.
A celebration of love and art, whatever the stripe or medium.
Will deliver to audiences who embrace a well-acted, written and directed story that immerses one in a rarified milieu of rustic charm.
movie_title: Le fils de l'épicier (The Grocer's Son) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Not much here is funny, the Chicago locations are drab, and the characters, as ordinary as they are, never develop into anything more than premise props.
The acting here is also worthy, but it's the conversation the film should generate that most excites.
Delivers the expected to audiences seeking intelligent, engaging entertainment with some tasteful melodramatic twists.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Sturdy Holocaust drama focusing on childhood and innocence amidst the horror takes the multi-Oscar-winning Life Is Beautiful to more harrowing and credible extremes. An original but somewhat contrived look at kids bonding across a death camp's barb
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Idiosyncratic doc about how Western pop culture helped pull back and ultimately ripped down the Iron Curtain provides a rare look at life in pre-1990 Estonia. Politicos will be intrigued.
movie_title: Disco and Atomic War (Disko ja tuumasoda) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Dense, energetic, occasionally indulgent but ultimately involving family drama, about the travails of a dysfunctional extended middle-class family who convene to celebrate Christmas, delivers gifts by way of a sterling cast led by Catherine Deneuve and Ma
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Van Sant's biopic prevails as a unique and sweeping cinematic experience that is both exhilarating and horrific.
Delightful, involving documentary about an unlikely couple who became pioneer contemporary art collectors with working-class salaries.
Dynamite ticking-bomb-thriller follow-up to the smash Da Vinci Code, about a cataclysmic device set to destroy the Vatican, will most certainly have explosive results at the box office.
Nia Vardalos, whose breakthrough came with the smash indie stunner My Big Fat Greek Wedding, again carries her lead role, but this vehicle feels far more manufactured and forced.
This handsome widescreen production about a spice-obsessed Greek professor's journey to adulthood mixes food, history and family ties very palatably and poetically.

Celebrated Canadian filmmaker Atom Egoyan ingeniously merges themes of family history, human psychology, politics, prejudice, terrorism and technology into an intriguing and intelligent drama that also works as a mystery.
A smash in its native country, this highly engrossing and stylized look at one of Italy's most notorious politicians is a triumph for filmmaker Paolo Sorrentino.
Eran Riklis again shows his gift for storytelling, affinity for fine acting, and sensitivity to a seemingly endless, complex and frustrating political standoff.

Fresh, terrific period drama that captures a swatch of middle-class Long Island suburbia. Solid cast and exceptional writing and directing make this impressive feature debut%u2014a kind of down-market American Beauty%u2014highly watchable and worth the de
While all kinds of notes-musical and otherwise-are sounded, none reverberate emotionally.

Superb documentary about the creation, birth and rebirth of American musical phenom A Chorus Line should rouse several generations of fans who will be swept away by nostalgia for a beloved classic and/or the thrilling drama captured here.

Corporate espionage caper in which two government operatives having amorous flings in various global stopovers decide to team up and go private to earn a bundle. Star power of Julia Roberts and Clive Owen and yummy locations fail to compensate for madly c

Intriguing, thought-provoking documentary about a pro-death-penalty lawyer and his unlikely relationship with a murderer on death row will satisfy socially conscious viewers on both sides of the ever-controversial issue.

A gaggle of upwardly mobile yuppies are buffeted by the stings of love and lust in an utterly charming, smart and very French take on the birds and the bees and the mysteries of coincidence. Dollops of both Woody Allen and Eric Rohmer enrich this romantic
movie_title: Un Baiser s'il vous plaît (Shall We Kiss?) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Minimalist in its approach and unconventionally structured, the film functions more as a stylistic exercise than an exercise in putting forth a hard-line political agenda or a sociopolitical point of view.
Electrifying drama about a jury at odds pays respectful homage to Sidney Lumet's classic 12 Angry Men while exposing post-Communist Russia at its worst and time-resistant human nature at its best.

This delirious, delicious, deconstructing look at the recent real-world entry into fashion of reality-TV's first "Project Runway" winner Jay McCarroll should round up the usual suspects of gay, style-conscious viewers and many others eager for a good time

Unpleasant concoction attempting to link soldiers on a drunken, sex-filled holiday beach leave with their horrific, sadistic behavior at an Abu Ghraib-like Iraqi prison is literally nauseating, no thanks to camerawork gone wild.

This polished Belgian diamond of a comedy-drama, about a hot-tempered, foul-mouthed working-class wife and mother jolted out of a nasty rut by an unlikely but problematic younger lover, completely rocks.

Utterly delightful, fact-based story of how a loving but unruly yellow Labrador brings joy and occasional tsuris to a young Florida couple and their offspring makes for perfect holiday entertainment. Families, dog lovers and even demanding breeds of filmg

Making a hilarious jab at the self-help masses and their worked-up gurus, this latest Jim Carrey vehicle affords him delicious comedic opportunities as a newly recruited adherent to a kind of "Positivism for Dummies" movement. Worshippers of Carrey's timi

Inspirational misfire about a guy seeking redemption by helping complete strangers has Will Smith in his grimmest role and his sloppiest movie. Whether his name can help this confusing film will be a big test of his star power.

Gripping period drama centers on an upper-class Berlin teen's furtive affair with a sexy but coarse tram worker. The liaison serves as a launch pad for a unique examination of German post-Holocaust guilt.

Small Aussie family drama about a likeable teen's acceptance of his severely disturbed older brother is a sweet and sunny charmer that will be a tough sell at theatres but should find its way home to smaller screens.
Quote not available.

Norma Rae goes U.K., as many will quip in response to this thoroughly enjoyable, spunky drama based on the true events that brought women closer to pay equality with men at Britain's Dagenham Ford factory.

Utterly captivating rom-com/drama about a wholly assimilated young Indian sous-chef at an upscale Manhattan eatery who finds himself shouldering his tradition-bound parents' crumbling Queens restaurant.

Utterly charming, visually sumptuous and often witty, this new 3D musical rendition of the old fairy tale...will delight youngsters and teens while holding the attention of the more hair-challenged among audiences.

Emotionally raw drama conveys the very bad behavior and "detached" states of many in the vortex of a prototypical Long Island public school. Independent filmmaking at its very best and a must-see for teens and their elders.
This bleak look at the hardship imposed by a monstrous parent and his downfall won't be worth a detour for most audiences.
A stunning debut, with a fascinating subject, an array of plain-folk talking heads, and precious access to a besieged community.
Drama about a failed and depressed 'Ugly American' New York writer attempting some kind of regeneration in Paris follows its 'hero' into degeneracy.
Audiences who embrace high-quality, smartly produced documentaries about compelling and worthy subjects will get their money's worth.
movie_title: How Much Does Your Building Weigh, Mr. Foster? (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A kinetically pummeling powerhouse that carries its own payload of appealing qualities.
Nifty spy actioner featuring impressive big-screen newcomer and martial-arts expert Gina Carano as a high-level, high-kickin' intel operative for hire but not to mess with.

Terrific contemporary drama about a veteran Queens, New York roadie who's been sacked after decades hauling equipment for Blue Oyster Cult is a gripping portrait of a flawed loser that allows Ron Eldard to shine
Powerful, somewhat flawed drama is packed with important themes, fine acting and emotional tugs.
Winner of a dozen awards in eight countries, this 2001 Dutch children's comedy-adventure will delight kids and parents alike.
Albert Nobbs has the packaging and promise of something quite special, but there's too much narrative bubble wrap inside.

This handsomely produced, richly detailed documentary about how the tobacco industry strove to hook America on nicotine and how the research scientist in charge upended this mission as whistleblower is as entertaining as it is informative.
Charming, short tribute to Lebanese filmmaker's beloved Beirut grandmother, her memories and deep-rooted values is more home movie than big-screen-worthy, but will warm up any screen.
An original that recalls the whimsy and charm of previous Gallic hits Amélie and Chocolat.
Strictly for art-house fans impervious to things bizarre, offensive and indulgent.
Award-winning Spanish documentary about World War II's most infamous double agent eventually evolves into a fascinating exposé of highly creative and unconventional espionage work.
Fascinating documentary about the iconic American design team and their studio that defined an enduring modernist look.
movie_title: Eames: The Architect And The Painter (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A heap o' feel-good, wholesome, splashy fun.
Jarecki gets fine performances from all hands.
Terrific star-packed documentary takes viewers onstage, backstage, into car-service back seats and onto New York streets with Paul McCartney just after 9/11 as he muses warmly and wisely...
This delicious satire daring to depict current French President Nicolas Sarkozy's recent rise to power is a real upscale art-house pleaser.
Hard-hitting Brazilian thriller about police corruption, politics and crime colliding in Rio's favelas and corridors of power and law enforcement is as intelligent as it is entertaining.
Adam Sandler playing both an ambitious ad guy and his loser female twin is a brazen high concept that provides mostly comedic lows. But Sandler fans may welcome the brainless diversion.
A pleasant trifle of bright performances, narrative zigzags and tensions and the occasional visual fun of split-screens.

This latest in the raunchy, pot-infused franchise hits new "high" marks as it bestows a terrific Christmas present on fun-seeking, broad-minded filmgoers young and old, brainy and brainless, who share an aversion to "tea parties" and dumb prejudices.

Sad, timely and affecting documentary about this country's bullying epidemic will move audiences but should wake up educational and law-enforcement authorities to take action rather than let these abuses continue.
