Hong Sangsoo's character development and, similarly, relationship progression never develop beyond the slam-bang aspects of romance.
movie_title: Woman is the Future of Man (2004)

movie_review_blurb: An affectionate, comprehensive overview of Hollywood's blockbusters and bombs.
A delightful diversion.
Dragging along in a tedious rhythm of long-take, big-talk, Hamaca Paraguaya is a cinematic bust.
Art School likely will entertain a sophomoric audience and etch some winning college-kid figures, but art house audiences will be disappointed by its paint-by-numbers storytelling.
Tthose who reveled in such cinematic synapses as the eyeball being slit in Un Chien Andalou will gravitate toward this outrageous, and frequently hilarious, piece de film.
It is smartly and convincingly fleshed out, at least enough to fit inside and burst the seams of generic dimension.
A deliriously funny romantic roundelay.
A moving drama of one young mother's drug addiction.
At its most stimulating, Moustache is a keen glimpse into a marriage that appears perfect on the surface but when examined shows its deficiencies.
After a while, the crudeness and venality of the central characters proves as stifling as the incessant Queens summer heat does to our dubious protagonists.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A brainy blend of farce and heart, this is one of those movies that veteran moviegoers complain they don't make anymore.
Distilled to a more endurable length, this insightful odyssey might best serve as a required text for graduating medical students and hospital administrators.
Develops slowly, almost painfully so, but those mature viewers who stay with it will embrace a mature and stirring glimpse of 'true love' in one of its three vignettes.
The narrative is so scant that watching the film's weather is the chief pleasure.
It's unlikely that even the most sophisticated or jaded of festival audiences will kindly endure the onslaught of viciousness on display.
Visually, Free Zone resembles a home movie in which an overly enthusiastic vacationer records every moment of a mundane trip.
Kilometre Zero offers a searing look into the horrors the people of Iraq, specifically the Kurds, suffered under the brutish tyranny of Saddam Hussein.
Only when the multicultural conceit of vastly different musical traditions blending to produce a transcendent sound is muted does the film finally jell.
movie_title: Crossing the Bridge: The Sound of Istanbul (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Pithy and highly amusing.
Plodding and predictable.
5 Days should enthrall viewers interested in the Israel-Palestinian conflicts, as well as those generally interested in prescriptive conflict resolution.
A missed-love story with people you don't care about.
The film's horrific and important subject matter is distilled into a lackluster lump of generic buddy-movie/road-picture components.
A warm family drama pops through the seams of a film within-a-film about Silvio Berlusconi.
More a home movie than a documentary film.
Amazingly dunderheaded.
Chock full of elements that never spark beyond one-sheet dimension.
The imagery of the classic movie, where a spirited red balloon wafts unpredictably over Paris, never even attempts to reach a metaphorical height, nor does it even engage us compositionally.
movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This girl-talk comedy is a cut below its predecessors.
Evinces an appealing sentimentality without being maudlin or only puppy-dog cute.
Mired by director Cherie Nowlan's indelicate direction. Nowlan pumps the drama, as well as the comedy, to blaring pitch. Similarly, several attempts at cutesiness slog down into rank contrivance.
A stirring and heart-wrenching statement of the horrible powers that mankind holds in its fist.
movie_title: White Light/Black Rain: The Destruction of Hiroshima and Nagasaki (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A frothy delight, robust with strong and conflicted characters.

Chapter 27 is a smart attempt to distill the twisted psychology and motivation of Mark David Chapman, which we've all superficially gleaned through mass-media reports and intermittent updates on Chapman's incarceration.
A brilliant house-of-horror tale with Hitchcockean flair.

Son of Rambow is pumped up with all the right kids' ingredients: slapstick, fantasy, alienation and severe adult authority figures. But screenwriter and director Garth Jennings has slammed them all together with little cohesion.
A rousing documentary on the street children of Cairo, These Girls is an agonizing and uplifting depiction of street survival at its most daunting.
A masterful distillation of explosive elements: science, art, psychology and humanity.
movie_title: Wonders Are Many: The Making of Doctor Atomic (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An uplifting yarn as a young American Indian ventures from the reservation.
Samuel L. Jackson knocks out a championship performance in this gritty, uplifting tale about an ex-boxer.
Year of the Dog ambles with both light humor and dark insights. Filmmaker Mike White's easy comic touch graces the storyline, unleashing some amusing comic characters, as well.
While often hard to watch because of its unflinching portrayal of the ugliness that love can take, Snow Angels succeeds because of the depth of its well-drawn characters.
A touching and unlikely romance that is no gloss but all heart and brains.

We can hear the French barking "auteur" already... Beneath the profanely preposterous premise, Stay is a rather sweet and conventional love story that perambulates around the notions of trust and acceptance.
This well-made film illuminates the power of a charismatic personality in rousing the multitudes.
In this affectionate glimpse into those countercultural times, filmmaker Stuart Samuels has compiled an engaging distillation of those nocturnal filmic emissions.
movie_title: Midnight Movies: From the Margin to the Mainstream (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Much brainier than a John Waters opus, Avida eructs with deadpan hilarity through a series of nonsequential comic set pieces.

Scene after scene of verbose fiddle-faddle: Characters orate at each other, while sitting in cars, sitting at dining tables, sitting in living rooms, sitting at office desks. The film might be better titled The Big Sit.
A misguided blasphemy of "Bicycle Thief," downloaded through film-noir affectations, this Competition Entrant is morally specious and narratively nonsensical.
Predictable and narratively uninspired, this Un Certain Regard entrant is unlikely to generate interest beyond its homeland.
Launches into the audience-pleasing stratosphere with a brainy, unpredictable story orbit.

Screenwriter-director Brewer transcends his generic story, laying out his beat from each character's heart. We come to know their inner fears and demons, including those of some particularly well-drawn supporting characters.
An extremely well-modulated and mature work, especially for a first-time filmmaker.
The Jacket is not likely to be everyone's cup of tea, but filmmaker John Maybury has forged a mesmerizing mindblower.
Those who survive it emerge in a shell-shocked euphoria -- so good and so blunt is the writing.
Despite the evocative aesthetics evincing the hollow state of modern love life, the film never percolates beyond a monotonous whine.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Money (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Intelligently crafted and often insightful.
An insightfully cheeky entertainment.
In every respect, director Gary Winick has served up a delectable, entertaining film.
In this involving film of three decidedly different women, filmmaker Rebecca Miller has distilled some gripping character portraits.
It's a vibrant, embracing film of people on the fringe of mainstream America.
An engrossing portrait of a man whose engaging manner and flamboyant style made him a truly larger-than-life character.
movie_title: The Kid Stays in the Picture (2002)

movie_review_blurb: In general, the film is a series of Broomfield popping up Michael Moore-style, unannounced, and drilling the unsuspecting subjects with invasive and blunt questions.
An absorbing, slice-of-depression life that touches nerves and rings true.
It smartly delineates the hard choices that people without many options must make, and its treatment of their conflicted situations is respectful but highly comic.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the Midlands (2003)

movie_review_blurb: 'Butterfingered' is the word for the big-fisted direction of Jez Butterworth, who manages to blast even the smallest sensitivities from the romance with his clamorous approach.

Tarantino's lined up a fine cast to play his assorted snotwads, grimeballs, sleazoids, small-timers, druggies and bulletheads in this 1990s version of a down-and-dirty 1940s pulp fictioner, the kind Dash Hammett and the boys used to crank out.
A sobering and powerful documentary about the most severe kind of personal loss: rejection by one's mother.
An uneven mix of dark satire and childhood awakening.
movie_title: The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Despite some harsh patterns, it's a stunningly warm tapestry of human beings struggling to endure despite all things.
An absorbing and unsettling psychological drama.
Provides both a searing satire of modern suburbia and provocative insight into the malignant maturation of generally well-meaning and privileged kids.
We're left with a voyeuristic view of some strangers' lives whom we're never interested in other than, of course, an initial prurient curiosity.
There are fine performances and smart comic flourishes throughout.
A wild ride with eight boarders from Venice Beach that was a deserved co-winner of the Audience Award for documentaries at the Sundance Film Festival.
A thoughtful and compassionate story of a young girl.
A sobering, highly entertaining insight into the innards of that up-and-down business world.
It's sophisticated, both intellectually and morally!
A generally tasty entertainment that is both engaging and uplifting.
In pacing and vitality, this is almost as listless as its drab lead character.
At its best, Bark! has some good bits, but it also has some numbingly irritating sequences.
In this day of dummying-down and coddling students, it's refreshing to see a teacher push his students to levels of accomplishment they didn't think was possible.
LaBute hammers this Shape to smithereens with argument after argument.
A searing story of addictive behavior.
Playing at 158 minutes, Mondovino's essence would be more flavorful, as well as powerful, if distilled to half that time.
The film is not sheer wizardry; it also has heart.
A superb coming-of-age film with international appeal.
Estes has crafted a realistic and rich portrait of the moral dilemmas that adolescents experience.
A smartly scoped story of great personal growth and transformation.
Told with a tender vigor, the film explores relationships on a number of levels.
A grand story of redemption, laced with barbecued wit and slopped with intrigue.
Delirious sendup of girl-power films.
A stunning, difficult film.

Throughout, we're constantly rooting for Maria, aware of her underlying decency and protective of her missteps.
[A] smart insight into modern-day relationships.
Hats off to Michael Polish for his otherworldly slants on the barren expanse of this far-out Americana essay.
A sleek psychological thriller outwitted by its own hyper craftsmanship.

Nicely enough, it's packed with droll humor and smart compassion.
It is both piercingly insightful and kindhearted.
Both an appealing coming-of-age yarn and, as Monsieur Ibrahim embraces his own mortality, a heartfelt coming-of- aging saga.

movie_review_blurb: A chokehold of a movie, grabbing us but not ultimately engaging us.

A masterful film and a bracing movie experience.

[A] full-bodied and thoughtful HBO documentary.
Both a comprehensive personality profile, as well as a smart depiction of Americana.

veteran filmmaker Stanley Nelson has crafted a searing portrait of those violent, racist times. Intelligently composed and powerfully driven, Freedom Summer is a stirring historical document. It would seem an essential addition for any university library.

Compelling insight into the staggering pressures faced by court-appointed public defenders.

There is plenty of violence. But anyone expecting the wrath of Kahn will have to wait for the sequel.
In the Pixar animation universe, all things are possible. More important, they are plausible.
No one can tell a coherent story anymore, and before long no one will notice.
And any film that plants such ideas in the cultural compost heap should be commended. Here's hoping they bloom.
Hellboy II has the inclinations of a gas guzzler but the soul of a hybrid, and the two resist each other like partners in a loveless marriage.

movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The Dark Knight is better than you have heard and as good as you had hoped.
Camp, bawdy and with a perky innocence, it is Sex and the City meets High School Musical.

A decade has passed since the last film based on the show, which went off the air in 2002, and while I had few expectations for the sequel, the depth of my disappointment is proportional to my lingering affection for the characters and the concept.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: [It] won the audience award at the Sundance Film Festival this year and has all the variables such an honor implies and demands: naughty topic, quirky performances, hangdog sensibility and hint of redemption.
Its scope is broad -- it has three flashbacks in the first 10 minutes before sticking with the 1920s and 1930s -- but its focus is sharp.
Ashes of Time Redux, like that line from Hey Jude, takes a sad song and makes it better.
